title: Why this is the best bet.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2022
body: Most young big cats love heights and are fearless about attaining them--unless the height proves "tipsy."  They're no dummies.  They register the unstable or unbalanced surface in memory and choose not to return.  I was overly impressionable to photos of floor to ceiling "cat trees" without noticing that the base was no larger or heavier than the 3-4 platforms above it.  Certain disaster--not to your cat but to your ego, patience and even pocket-book.  Of course, you can try to secure the top of the tree to your ceiling BUT: 1. your cat may have made up it's mind re: the earlier instability of the tree; 2. your ceiling may not appreciate the drilling needed for a secure fastening; 3. secure or not, the weight of a 4-5 platform tree will eventually defeat the ceiling anchor.While this Amazon tree is not tip-proof, it's: 1. made for large cats; 2. it's tall but not to an excessive degree; 3. the base is wide enough to supply stability that's totally lacking in trees that make no distinction in the size of platforms.

title: A waste of money
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2021
body: This cat tree is, unfortunately, a complete waste of money.  It was very easy to put together and once it was assembled it felt quite sturdy.  My cats loved it so I thought I had hit a home run for them.  Here we are, five months later, and what I have is a carpeted piece of junk.On Amazon's picture you can see that the highest platform is flat but there is a cover that goes on with elastic which turns it into a bed with soft raised edges.  After a couple of months that platform started to wobble.  As you can see on Amazon's picture, it is attached to a box underneath it,  That attachment is a screw which screws the post onto the top of the box.  No amount of turning would tighten it back up so I just hoped for the best.The other day I finally heard the inevitable crash and went running in to find the platform and post had fallen off.  Once that happened I was able to see that the screw which attaches the post to the box is threaded into a piece of black plastic.  That piece of plastic is simply stapled to the scratching post.  If you look at my picture, you can see the round piece of black plastic on top of the box (ignore the post behind it, that's a separate tower).  The middle of that piece of plastic is threaded to hold the screw.  That connection is still strong, but the plastic goes inside the bottom of the scratching post and that is where it is attached with nothing but staples.  It's no wonder that the cats' frequent jumping on and off put lateral pressure on the staples until they finally lost their hold on the post.Now the second highest (flat) platform is starting to do the exact same thing.  I guess I could buy a staple gun and re-staple it, but even if I put twice as many staples in I'm not very confident that it won't end up doing the exact same thing.  What I'm left with is the base, a couple of scratching posts, and a box that sits about 2' off the ground which the cats can hide in--except they don't particularly care for that part.I'm sure all of these 5 and 4 star reviews are from people who haven't had this thing long enough to experience the loose and wobbly platforms, or ones that never bothered to come back and change their reviews.  If you decide to take a chance and buy this anyway, just make sure it's not next to anything that can get broken when these two pieces fall off.  That's "WHEN" and not "if".

body: I bought this for my cat in June 2020 and it has lasted until Sep 2021. After about a year it started to lean and joints became loose. Now when my cat jumps on it or sleeps on the top tier, It leans dramatically and sometimes she falls off when she rolls over (she lands on her feet so don't worry) I tried to tighten them but there was no use. My cat LOVED this tree, probably why it's falling apart now.I'm probably not going to buy again because I wished it lasted longer/was sturdier, especially because I replaced the sisal rope just a few months ago. BUT I am going to keep this in the back of my mind incase my cat hates the new tree I get her. She was obsessed.
